'16. Polling Day in Australia on Conscription.

Reported in Durban daily that Holman, Beeby & Wade had formed a National Govt. whose main object is the successful termination of the

 

War & therefore to direct people's attention & all state energies 
towards
 that end.

At present sailing along the coast of S. Africa with Durban Lighthouse just sinking astern. Hilly country - many villages & fine scenery apparently.

We all have pleasant - very - recollections of the kindness of the Durbanites. Durban a very pleasant city - rather warmer and moister than Sydney. Greenery everywhere. Roads very fine - some blocked, most asphalted.



all beautifully smooth. Spent
Entry.60:
days at Durban the first day unfortunately as Ship's Orderly Officer
s
. Practically everything done by Kaffirs & coolies. Zulus are Rickshaw men very powerful and well built. Native police very big & have a high opinion of themselves. Seem very effective, the Zulus & other natives seem afraid of them.Zulus men got great harvest from the Australians. Men scrambled considerable money among kaffirs- throwing water upon themwhile in a bunch on the ground.

 

Tram-carselectric on same system as Sydney but all single cars & 
double deckers
. All soldiers travelled free upon invitation of Municipal Council which also provided free admission to Zoo, Baths Botanic Gardens.Municipal control of trains & all abovementioned. Beach Parade very fine with Children's paddling bains& large opensea baths barred in. Durban notorious for sharks. (water)

Durban people have given Germans a bad time, having burned down practically



every German shop on an organised system even the marines called out to protect the property assisting in its destruction. Natal very loyal, but Durbanites report great disloyalty among the Dutch all over the Union.

Y.M.C.A. & Methodists especially good to our men, the YMCAproviding eg. 2 eggs, bread, butter & tea for 4d & the Methodists providing free tea & cake etc.

We had 3 route marches & were enthusiastically welcomed. Many ladies



threw hundreds of oranges & nachis(mandarins) onto the boat both on our drawing in & pulling out. Ostrich feathers cheap. I bought 3 for Jess for £1 & a boa for 25/-. Registered them home.

I visited Zoo by rickshaw with Petteson, paid 5/- Dined at Durban Club - very fine club - as guest of local commandant - Colonel Wylie - with two other local colonels Col. Onslow, our OC & our two medicos. Made very welcome



Every house has native servants - nurse girls, gardeners etc.

Native bosses carry sticks to beat men lazy or others in the way.

Attended Pierrotrehearsal for concert next evening. Singing rather poor & acoustic qualities of the Town Hall bad.-

Visited Umbilo, Bentley's sister - Mrs. Eaton - lives at Durban. Natives in every trade except plastering which Australian workmen run & will not instruct natives in

Tram-Parcel delivery a good idea. Buy a penny ticket & place on parcel & pay another 1d on Delivery at second parcel depot, ie a shop where arrangements have been made to reserve such parcelry.

Another good idea new to Sydney - Children's paddling basins, also enclosure for surfing safe from sharks.

Entry.66:
Still beautifully calm weather. Called at St Vincent in Cape Verde Islands. Very dry & desert-like place.

Business - what there is - is evidently controlled by British. WilsonSons & Co supply the coal. Water has to be brought from another island. It rains here about 4 days a year. Natives dived well for coins, catching themunder the water. A fine silhouette of a man's head - resembling George Washington was formed by the mountain near St. Vincent.

Large important Cable station here.

"Donegal" - "Ophir". Crossing the Line men ducked each other to their heart's content, (also a few officers) - particularly Engineers. Cartoon by one of the infantry too on the ducking of Engineers - "In memory of the Fallen Engineers who fell to the level of the common Infantry. "By Gawd, the taint!!"

Flying fish very plentiful to St Vincent - A few since.

My NCO's in responsible positions - Beresford

as Ship's Q.M.S has done excellently, being praised on all sides. Corp. Coady assisting him has also received great praise - Coady taught at Newtown.

Serg. McGrath (appointed Corporal for drunkeness early in Voyage) since assisting Beresford & doing his work well. Serg
Clarke
 is Troop deck Sergeant for Sergeants' Mess - doing good work.

Serg. Burns our own troop deck Sergeant

has best troop deck on the ship. Looks after the men well.

Serg. Marsh is my Sergeant of Boatlwardassisted by newly appointed Corporals White, R.J.C & Douglas (Returned Soldier) S.S.M.
Lord
 doing well with our Company Sergeants Fox & Crichton also. Crichton a telegraphist is a fine 
signaler

Entry.67:
Cold with rough Sea. Very rough the past two days. An

exceptionally heavy gale was reported from South of Ireland, Queenstown, suffering severely. Seasick for two days - better today. Bently sent to hospital yesterday with Mumps.

We are about 700 miles west of Brest. After leaving St Vincent we narrowly escaped a submarine working evidently from 
Las
 
Palmas
 as base. It sank a Portuguese steamer on our track just a few hours ahead of us,



We received its S.O.S. signals and steered clear. Had photo taken with A.I.F. officers belonging to M-. Got Father O'Regan in the group. While being taken had bag with about £15 in it stolen. Officers made up the amount verygenerously.

Entry
Entry.96:
On Fatigue work clearing old German trench and making it into a leading drain for several roads. Very sticky & heavy work. The Engineer Officer in charge of the work stated that the 13th Battn worked better than any other Austrn. Battalion he had ever had working for him.

Snow fell from 10.30 am to 1pm. I made my first snow ball.

Visited F- where salvaging of German dug-outs is in progress. I was surprised at the number & size of these.

 

Yesterday (10th) with Padre Rettie I visited King George Hill. Here there is a notice board where the King stood to observe part of the Somme battle.

There was a tremendous struggle here in the early part of the Somme push. Two large mines had exploded leaving immense craters. Without seeing this hill one could never imagine the battering it must have had as evidenced by the thousands of shell holes. Many graves here - both British & German. Passed a

 

German cemetry coming back to camp.

Played Bridge after mess with Major Sparks, Lt Mills/Intelligence & Doc Shirlow. Lost 5 francs. Inspection of huts today by Brig-Gen Brand & Col Durrant.

Was pleased to hear from me that his wife (whom I had met at Cleggs) was looking very well when I saw her last August.

-Yarn-

A soldier from this Battn. was on Traffic Duty along the busy roads

passing this camp. It was important to keep traffic controlled & to Right of the road. The 
Grenadier Guards
 came along the middle of the road. "Keep to the Right" Billjim ordered. "
We're the Guards
.""Keep to the Right then." "We're the
Guards
 man; we're the 
GUARDS.
""Well I don't care if you're the bloody engine drivers you've got to keep to the right." He had his way too.

When the Brig. heard it he remarked "That man ought to be made a Lance Cpl."

Took my fatigue party of 90 the day before yesterday to Tricourt baths where we all had a hot shower & a change of underclothing & socks - new stuff being given for old. Much appreciated by all. Snow fell twice yesterday also small hailstones.

Entry.100:
Had a very pleasant evening last night at mess, our Battn having invited 
the
Brigadier Brand& CO's of the Brigade - Col Mc Sherry, Col Brockman Col Peck, Major Wilton

"Yank" Parray told several yarns, sang a song & got merry. All present (24) named my autograph book.

 =
Yarn
=

Our chaps raided Fritz's trench the other night & captured half-a-dozen Boschs, among them being a realGerman Corporal who resented being captured by "Australians". He strenuously objected to being led back to our lines, refused to come. Two Billjims lugged him in spite of his strugglings. However they were

still in No Man's Land when the time came near for our barrage to start & it became necessary to reach our lines quickly. Still Fritz Corporal struggled. Then No1 Billjim took a Mills Grenade, withdrew the pin and dropped it in Fritze's pocket. Then 
giving
leaving Fritz to himself he called out "Run like blazes Bill, I've put a b-turnip in his pocket." When they next looked over their parapet there was no sign of the bombastic Corporal.

Entry.101:
Everything was covered with deep snow this morning. Abeautiful & novel sight for us. It was very deep. We enjoyed snowbaling each other immensely.

I was 'prosecutor' in a F.C.M. but had nothing to do.

George (brother) sent a message from Adelaide (France) that he would like to see me before going into the line tomorrow. I visited Adelaide this evening about 2 miles away & met him coming back from visiting me. He was very well - 24 yesterday & quite cheerful.

He gave me 50 francs, insisting on my taking it 
either for myself or Reg
.

Wrote last night to a girl who sent a pair of knitted socks to a soldier. I received these socks on Xmas Eve. Her address

Flora Jolly, Mount St. Wycheproof, Victoria. Fritz is shelling our locality fairly consistently this evening.
Entry.102:
Unloading sleepers during the morn.Drainage work in afternoon. Tried my

gas helmet in a tear gas room. It's quite OK. During the morning I asked 10 men to push 8 railway trucks along the line. They didn't think they could move them & were very much surprised when they did the job easily. One wit exclaiming "Blime, if we can do that on Bully Beef what could 
be
we do on steak & Onions for Breakfast."

"There'd be no use for locomotives" said another.

Entry -
Entry.103:
Left Mametzthis morning

with Mills & Parsonage to examine the front position we are soon to take over. We 
drove
rode to Montauban Camp & left our horses with "A" Coy. Then had a long walk along duckboards 
to
through Delville Wood to Bde & Battn Hqrs. Then with a runner we set out to visit our trenches. The runner got off his track. We passed near heavy shell fire to - Road. Here we were shelled. Upon returning we had just started when two shells almost got us. The first passed over our

heads, while the second lobbed about 5 yards from me. Fortunately it was a dud - the first of 30 hells that had lobbed near us that afternoon.

Dined at A&D Coy at Montauban on reurning. Roads were frozen hard so our horses could only walk.
Entry.104:
Took Holy Communion this morning from Padre Rettie our Chaplain. Walked to Adelaide Camp this afternoon on the chance of seeing George but he had gone up the line

A 79 reinforcement to our battn. arrived containing a fair number of my own reinf. men.

A Zeppelin passed near us tonight in the darkness.



Entry
Entry.105:
No entry while in the lines - reserve or front - as our Battn. went into lines I went forward to take over from 45. Met Lt Terrace coming out near Quarry Siding. Lived Gap Tr. for 8 days and on Fatigue Work.

on M.G. emplacements. Joined by Bentley who went to "A" Coy.

I/C reserve 1/2 Coy in Possum T. for 2 nights while D.P.W., Cooney & Doust took 1/2 Coy into Greuse T. Camped in Dugout with Capt McDonald OC "C" Coy Lts Lanagan (Bourke dentist) & Turner (Bill) from near Brewarrina. Visited Shine T with Capt Murray 1st night, Grease T
Entry.106:
night.

Battn attack on Stormy T N.9. Euendecourt.Wonderful barrage which we watched for a few seconds,

bursting in German Trench about 15 yards ahead of us. After 2 minutes the barrage lifted & we quickly had the trench.

My platoon (8) captured a Machine Gun, store of bombs & bombing post (forming a strong point) near big dugouts) and a trench mortar for throwing pineapples.

My Sergeant Cross did good work, also MOs.

Pte Finlayson
 hopped over parapet & brought back wounded German under heavy double barrage

He was killed shortly after. 
Pte Lord
 (my old CSM of reinf. Coy)was wounded in head. Coady (teacher of Newtown) an old corporal of my reinf. was wounded in both arms escorting prisoners back. Marsh an old serg. of my reinf. also wounded. I wrote Cobar paper about Finlayson (my sergeant of works at Kiama whom I knew at Canbelego as Sec. P.L.L.

The Germans counter attacked several times the same night. We captured the trench at 10.2 pm after a 2 minute barrage

In these counterattacks they shelled & bombed us heavily. Capt McDonald (C) was killed early. Lt Bentley (A) killed about midnight a shell 
5.9
 bursting close to him & a piece evidently penetrating his heart. Lts Trim, Palling & Kell also wounded in "A". Capt Murray with A on Rt, McDowell with bombers on Left.Capt Bone, Lt Morgan, Lt Shirtley with D.Another Corp. of my reinf. - Bruce killed in A Experienced officers & men described the German bombardment as the

heaviest ever experienced by them, and far heavier than at Pozieres. It was concentrated upon the 800 yards of trench captured & therefore very severe. The Germans captured had no stomach for fighting & surrendered quiely. My platoon (17 effective men on account of a large carrying party being detailed captured a Machine Gun, Bombing post with big store of bombs and a Trench mortar for throwing pineapple bombs. We afterwards tried this mortar with good
Entry.107:
Settled down at La Chausee at 4 Div. School of Instruction - a general all round brush up and a kind of supervised rest.

Went to Abbeville on Saturday for weekend & returned yesterday (Sunday) afternoon.Sent Jess from Abbeville set of midget vases & three photos for framing. This is the
Entry.108:
School day. Last week I had a long ride through St Vast, St Saveur - across the Somme & through Picquiqny back to Chausee. The madame I am billeted gives me a

hot brick every night for my feet which are still rather sore after the Trenches. During the assault on 
Stormy Trench
 I was hit on leg slightly which left my knee a little tender. I was also 
shell shocked
 for a few hours after being almost burned by a shell landing on our parados against my head. Lt Hanagan put me to bed with a good dose of rum. This made me OK after about 2 hours good sleep. - my only sleep for 5 days & nights. I am just about myself again however with

a good bed every night & not too much to do each day.

Entry
Entry.109: Received letter from Jay, H. Connell & Cook (London) J's letter dated
Entry.110:
H.C. wished to be remembered to D.P. Wells (Capt). I wrote Jay & D.P.W.

Cooks informed me that the doll I forwarded through them to Merlie was lost in "Port Adelaide" 
torpedoed by Germans


Poor kiddy will be very disappointed, as I myself am.

Entry -
Entry.111:
-

In train between Amiens & Boulogne - proceeding to England on duty at Training Battalion.

Arriving at Victoria, three ladies evidently thought I was lost for they kindly offered information. I was OK however. Took them to afternoon tea at A.B.C. fot their kindness.

Went to Boarding House at Brixton near Newport Road. Rode on bus through London in darkness - walked a good deal of he way back.
Entry.112: Spent day in London - Visited A.I.F. Headquarters - drew £7 - met Capt. D.P. Wells my O.C. just returning to France after his Blighty leave. Went to Fulham for my trunk but it was not there. (It had not been sent from Codford).Visited St Pauls Cathedral - several central London streets. This evening I was knocked down by taxicabin dark street. Went to Kenninton Theatre & saw the Silver King".
Entry.113: - At Bungalow Hotel for the night at Tidworth met Colonel Persee White. Left Brixton this morning at 11am, delivered parcel from France for Lt W. Clasperto Miss -of Bayswater. Drove in Taxi through Hyde Park.Left London at3pmfor Tidworth
Entry.114:
Reported at Tidworth Arrived at Codford at 5pm after spending 2 hrs at Salisbury where visited the beautiful Cathedral - quite unique in its dainty simplicity.

Welcomed at 4th T.B. by

St Smith & Major Twynam & others I had met before. They had received report of my death in France.
Entry.117: Very cold. Concert in Y.M.C.A Hall by Miss party from Bristol - A troupe.Raining
Entry.120: -Commenced my Leave.Left Camp at 6.30 - walked to Codford Stn.
Entry.121: Very tired this morning & slept until midday in a very comfortable bed. After my late breakfast I came into Blackfriars, then visited St Paul'sCathedral, Whitechapel, Tower Bridge & as far as Stepney Green. Dined at 3pm at restaurant near Charing Cross Tube Station. Then "tubed" to Kennington & took bus to Streatham.
Entry.123:
Got up at 9.30, breakfasted and "bused" to 
Westminister.
 Raining and cold.
Entry.124:
Train

Sir Robt Buckle

Mayor of Oxford

Breakfasted at I
vanhoe
 Hotel.A Mrs M.F. Webster & her daughter Miss Norah Lang-Anderson sat at my table & entered into a conversation. We all knew several 
mutual
Australians over this way.

Left London for Bath at 5pm. Travelled with Sir Robt Buckle Mayor of Oxford to Didcot. He was very interested in Australia and knew our politics fairly well. He was an intimate friend of B Wise, - They were at

Oxford University together as Undergrads. A fine old man whose company and conversation I enjoyed thoroughly.

Arrived at Bath at 8.30pm - stayed at Argyles Temperance Hotel near the station.
Entry.125:
- Got up at 9.30 - visited three schools by tram - walked the streets for an hour, then went through the Pump Room & Roman Baths. Drank a little of the water which was not very pleasant and also sickly on account of being lukewarm

During the afternoon I attended Bath Abbey to hear the Avondale Choir, Abbey was filled, the Choir was excellent and the music - organ violins etc also.

During the later after I climbed the hill across the Avon from bath, had a beautiful walk through the pretty park with exquisite views on all sides. The view of Bath from Beacham Cliff is one ever to be remembered - the grey city, all spires and greenery backed by hills made more beautiful even than nature by art -
Entry.126:
Left Bath 8-10am. Spent 2 hours at Bristol walking about the streets. Bristol seems an extremely busy city - there are great smoking Chimney stacks on all sides - trains are busy, trucks loaded & barges on canals in every direction.

On the journey from Bristol to Plymouth I had an interesting companion - one who was constantly travelling in connection with some war industry. He explained the whole journey to me. I viewed Athelney where Alfred the Great held out

The country here is still marshy. Passed Bridgewater near where Sedgemoor was fought, Taunton famous or infamous for Judge Jeffreys; beautiful Exeter - the Exe valley, the channel on our left and Dartmoor on our right.

Arriving at Plymouth it was raining heavily.I found Jesse's grandfather and two aunts who were delighted and surprised to see me. They were all very well.Jesse's aunt Rose is so very small that I felt awkward walking with her.I took her to tea

Spent the evening with J's other aunt & then with the old man - a very interesting old chap.

Found a room at Colville's Cafe near Millbay station.

Slept in until 11am. Spent afternoon on Plymouth Hoe. Had tea with J's grandfather & aunt. Took aunt to the Theatre Royal to see "Hobson's Choice". Visited Devonport.
Entry.127:
Explored old Plymouth with the old man who explained everything.

During the evening I spent an hour walking on the Hoe. The searchlights were very picturesque. Eddystone was plainly visible with a bright flash.Very few boats in the harbour compared with my first visit - ie my arrival from Australia.
Entry.128:
- Sunday

Took the old man & Aunt in taxi to dinner at Mrs Lillicraps. Very pleasant afternoon spent.Snowing heavily all the day on and off.

Took aunt to Band



Concert on the Hoe Pier at night.
Entry.129:
- Left Plymouth for Exeter - snowing very heavily all the way & heavily all the afternoon in Exeter. Visited and explored the Cathedral - spending over an hour there. Took 3 tram rides to view the City and a long walk during which I visited the Gardens or Recreation grounds.

Stayed at Franklin's Temperance Hotel.
Entry.130:
Spent the morning

visiting the ancient Guild Hall where I had an excellent guide, the St Nicholas Priory - a venerable old building where there is also an excellent guide - the lady caretaker, and the old Rougement Castle.

I visited the Museum Public Library & Art Gallery - all very fine indeed and quite surprising in their completeness to me. Viewed Exeter Exmouth & district from the roof of my Hotel - a very good view

Bought several small vases with Coats of Arms on.

Snowing very heavily on and off all day - am at present in Waiting Room awaiting train to Taunton where I intend spending tonight & tomorrow.
Entry.131: Arrived at Taunton - Disappointed to find telegram at P.O. recalling me to camp. My C.O. had granted me leave until
Entry.132: but Group Headquarters had confirmed leave only to midnight
Entry.134:
hours in Taunton. Walked & saw as much as possible.

Had to wait
Entry.135: hours at Bristol. Explored by tram as much as possible. Paid
Entry.136:
for plate of meat & cup of coffee.

Reached Camp at 11.30 after long walk from Codford station.
Entry.138: Church Parade Good Friday & Easter Sunday- Padre very affected - sickening.Walked with Smith on Sunday to Steeple Langford.Had tea with Mr Frost, son/ R F C and two daughters -yarned until 9pm.
Entry.139: - Concert in YMCA by Mrs Fadden's party - very good concert. Draft left for France with Capt Paull & Lt Smith. A splendid send off. One volunteer wanted to leave with draft at 5 minute's notice.A young chap
Entry.140: volunteered before CO had finished his sentence.
Entry.142:
In bed with cold in head & chest -
 
12th 24th Rain in pm - marched in the evening.Sergeants are giving a dance.

Entry 19th April

At Codford

Left Codford
Entry.143:
with 4th Training Bn. and marched to Lark Hill Camp near Bulford, Bovington and -.We rested for lunch for 2 hours at Stonehenge which we all inspected.

Raining heavily when we arrived at Camp. The 1st Brigade Mess made us very welcome. A very fine mess they have. I met many officers I knew especially from "Ceramic"

Buckley of No. 8 School R.A.S. Sydney is Adjutant. Robertson, Wells (1st.) Brown
Entry.144:
were there.

Otto Brese whom I taught at William Street had just arrived with Reinforcement - as
Entry.145:
Lieut.

Had a very pleasant two nights at this camp. The review by the King was a magnificent sight.Reported that Australians were there. It made us all proud of Australia to see such men & such excellent marching. Butler of

my platoon was presented with Military Medal by King. We called him "little Tich". He is very popular among his fellows. Conversation between King & Butler as reported by a listener -
King
 - after speaking about the winning of the Medal continued "You are rather small for an Australian soldier are you not?" -
Butler
 - It's the best b-way to be over there Sir." The K laughed

and patted him on the back.

Entry
Entry.146:
At 24 Crescent Grove Clapham Common.Have just returned from theatre "The Maid of the Mountains" at Daly's Theatre with Merrifield & Major Twynam. -

Merrifield provided tickets. I met them at 138 Picadilly - the Australian Officers' Club.I arrived at Clapham Common on Monday to attend Officers' Bombing School

On Monday afternoon I visited Lewisham Military Hospital & saw Lex who was up for his first day with his foot still in plaster to prevent it dropping back.

Entry
Entry.147:
On Tuesday Merrifield shouted Theatre Party to Major Twynam & myself. We met at Australian Officers' Club 138 Picadilly & taxied to Daly's Theatre, "The Maid of the Mountains

was being played - Jose Collins being the maid.

On Wednesday 
night
 I met Merrifield at Criterion Restaurant, Picadilly near Tube, & had afternoon coffee & war cake. We then walked thro St James Park & afterwards had dinner at "The Florence" a beautiful white & glass room. Then we went to the Playhouse near the Embankment to see "The Passing of the Third Floor Back" - a very splendid serious society play.The artists were all stars.



and proceeds for Womens' Military Hospitals in Russia, Servia , France
Entry.148:
- Wednesday -

Just finished writing notes on Stokes' Guns - Last Saturday afternoon I took Lex out for a walk & then a bus ride through South East & East London. Sunday afternoon I took him my Australian hat & waterproof overcoat. I then walked from Victoria through Victoria Street to Trafalgar Square then through Hyde Park. Had supper at the

Cafe de l'Europe. Plenty of women & girls smoking cigarettes.
Entry.150: I visitedHorseferryRoad (A.I.F. Hqrs) & drew £6 pay & £4 travelling expenses in connection with my 1916 trips to France. I then spent about 40 mins in Westminister - House of Commons & heard a few speeches. Saw George Reid on right of Speaker.He looked very well.
